reviewText: Wonderful movie that I haven't seen in at least thirty years, and then it was on TV. No features, not unusual in a film from the thirty's, and a very decent copy with excellent clarity and sound.I'm very grateful that this movie, as well as "The Coriscan Brothers" has been done on a regular pressed DVD disk, not the damned DVD-R. In my researches I've found that one season stored in a hot and/or humid place can cause the DVD-R disks to degrade. Which is why the local library, may accept donations, but will not buy a DVD-R disk with their own funds.Now, I wonder where and for how much I can get Richard Chamberlains version of TCOMC?
summary: Great movie, thanks for not going the DVD-R route.

reviewText: This is the classic  film of THE COUNT OF MONTE CRISTO with Robert Donat.  A seaman takes over a returning ship and agrees to deliver a message to a man at the docks. Thus begins one of the wildest  adventures ever imagined.  Edmond Dantes is sent to the Dungeons where he not only survives, but in the years to follow goes from despair to anger to revenge and finally to justice under the care of the Abbey who is also a prisoner and who holds the secret of the island of Monte Cristo  and the means to secure justice for himself and the woman he loves.The is an old fashion story in Black and White, Some people may dismiss it. But if you have read the book and open to this well made film, you will share in one of the best stories, a true swashbuckler in the best tradition.
summary: you wil share in one of the best stories, a true swashbuckler in the best tradition

reviewText: This is a good film version, but some of the dialogue was unintelligible, the quality of the movie is mediocre, and it could have been a bit longer (especially the swordfight between Mondego & Monte Cristo and the final scene with Villefort); but these are minor quibbles. I also highly recommend the 2002 film version starring Jim Caviezel, Guy Pearce and Richard Harris. It follows the novel, albeit with many minor (and die-hard purists would say, major) digressions (hey, it's only 2/1/2 hours long; how much of a 1492 page novel can you cram into 2/1/2 hours?) and inserts Christian undertones (a very nice surprise for a Hollywood movie nowadays, and very commendable), but it retains the spirit of the novel. It's rated PG-13, but I think it should have been rated PG. I don't recommend the 1999 miniseries starring Gerard Depardieu because it contains a blasphemous scene, the beginning (Dantes' life before he was arrested and his time in prison) are exceedingly rushed and an unneccessary sex scene between Monte Cristo and a character invented for the miniseries. On the plus side, it tries hard to follow the novel, but the negatives I mentioned above far outweigh its feeble attempt to follow the original novel. I recommend the 1934 and 2002 film versions of Dumas' classic tale. This film is Not Rated.
summary: Good Film Version. I Recommend The 2002 Movie.

reviewText: A seaman accused of spying is imprisoned without trial and forced to spend the next ten years in solitary confinement. Aided by another prisoner, he makes a daring escape and adopts a new identity. Robert Donat stars in this classic swashbuckler based on the 1844 novel by French writer Alexander Dumas. Translated  into 100 different languages, it made Dumas one of the most widely read authors in the world.
summary: Great French tale by Alexander Dumas

reviewText: Alejandro Dumas' classic novel has never been better adapted. The slow process of moral degradation, injustice against this simple man will crash with a real boomerang when the circumstances surround him and through the loyalty and sincere friendship with an old man who is living his last days. This dying man will be for him the turn of the spinning wheel when he finds this treasure. After an astonishing  getaway, the soul scares and spirit wounds will make of him a powerful and unknown Count who meticulously will eliminate successively to every one of those who sent to prison.As you know the passionate reading who illuminated the mind of our early childhood, found in this case a notable screen adaptation. In this version Rowland Lee makes an impressive direction work supported by a glorious cast which made of this entry a remarkable classic in those far thirties.Robert Donat reached his artistic peak due this film. He would join with Hitchocok in Thirty nine steps.A golden gem!

reviewText: I enjoyed Robert Donat's 1934 "Count of Monte Cristo", though the film has a number of gaps of logic and very little swashbuckling (it does has one, quite fine, rapier duel).  Still, the story moves along apace and the two principal leads acquit themselves well.As for the suspensions of disbelief that don't stay suspended, these include the fact the Robert Donat's Edmond Dantes seems little bothered at his 16 years of unjust imprisonment in the Chateau d'If (he never conveys a sense of the agony and despair which that would entail), he falls too readily under the sway of the Abbe Feria (showing no suspicion of the eccentric fellow, despite everything he's been through), and as the Count of Monte Cristo he claims to be carrying out justice, rather than revenge.  Furthermore, he and Mercedes reconcile without ever explaining to one another what happened when Edmond was spirited away and Mercedes led to believe he had died, and all that transpired since.  The film climaxes with a rather preposterous court case wherein Edmond turns the tables on Villefort -- not at all in keeping with the book.All this is not to say that the film isn't enjoyable, but it is far inferior to the 2002 Jim Caviezel version.  In the latter, the motivations of the characters are logical, the action is far more extensive and thrilling, the casting is in every role superior, and the changes made from Dumas' story are actually improvements -- a very rare thing in book-to-film adaptations.  In short, all the deficiencies of the 1934 film are absent in the 2002 version.The critics generally rate the 1934 film above all others, but for my money, the 2002 is far and away the best.  Still, the 1934 film is better paced than most early 1930s films I've seen and the "Hen's Tooth" DVD features a good clean print and sound that isn't overly "hissy".

reviewText: I had looked forward to eventually see Robert Donat as the Count of Monte Cristo but alas! After so many years in the dungeons Donats hair is perefctly permanented and when the best of the novel by Alexandre Dumas is to come namely the Counts return and vengeance over his enemies  who put him away in prison, the film looses the very nerve of the plot. Why change the original plot into stupid theater and courtroom scenes without the thrill and wits of Dumas? Not that a film must follow the plot of the book in details but here a great story is turned into nonsense. And the ending is very unlikely and unfaithful to the novel and Dumas' great art. The print is not crisp but okay. And anyway! I AM grateful that this film now can be seen!

But a necessary part of the Donat canon to see and own.

reviewText: I read the complete unabridged Dumas novel last year............it was long ( Dumas was paid by the word ) but wonderful.  What a story teller he was..........Hollywood has used his stuff so often ( Three Musketeers, Man in the Iron Mask, Camille, and The Count of Monte Cristo ) he should be awarded a screen writing Oscar posthumously............and for good measure the opera La Traviata by Verdi is based on a Dumas play...........to repeat: this guy could tell a story.The Count can not be filmed as written...too long, too many sub plots, too unwieldy........so, adapting requires a lot of creativity.  This movie veers from the book a lot particularly in the end, but it is well adapted and the story flows very well.  I like this screenplay better than the 2002 version.The movie itself is pure delight...Elissa Landi is a great Mercedes, Robert Donat is magnificent as the Count, the actor,O.P. Heggie, who played the blind hermit in the Bride of Frankenstein does a wonder job as the Abbe, and film noir icon Louis Calhern makes a great villian as the magistrate who sends Edmund to prison.The pace, editing, and crisp dialogue all combine to make this the Count you want to keep.....great transfer on the dvd with darned good audio. Highest Recommendation!!
summary: The Count Has Never Been Better
Title: N/A

reviewText: I have always loved this movie inasmuch as it shows how a person who was badly wronged gets back at those who wronged him.  Edmond Dantes is a sailor who gets the Royal Shaft by a group of people who want him disposed of because some else wants the girl who loves him and whom he loves in return.  He is set up and falsely imprisoned on a set of trumped up charges.  How he escapes the prison, gains a fortune, and then settles the score with his antagonists is a classic piece of revenge served cold.  Admittedly it's an old black and white film, but well worth the price and well worth the watching.  If you're an aficionado of classic, old-time films, then this is a "must have" for you.

reviewText: Far more than most adaptations of novels, this version of THE COUNT OF MONTE CRISTO adheres to the novelist's plot and details, and does so to its advantage, as the original is wonderfully full-blooded. The role of Edmond Dantes is played well by Robert Donat, who nicely projects the many moments of peril with which his character deals. The imprisonment and escape scenes at the seabound Chateau D'If, although of a result certain to the viewer, are neatly mounted to create genuine compassion and suspense. Splendidly cast, a wide range of talent brings a quite good balance to each act. The passing from the early tableaux of adventure to the thrust of the story: carefully crafted and complex methods of revenge, is effectively delivered by the scenario. Those who decide to watch this classic film will avoid missing excellent acting from Sidney Blackmer and O.P. Heggie, as well as outstanding art direction and costume design.
summary: A Pledge Of Revenge Classically Filmed.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Even back when all that existed was the original Nostalgia Merchant VHS, this has always been my favorite version which is curious to a degree, because it is probably the least faithful adaptation of the story to the screen.  I have never heard of Hen's Tooth Video before this, but believe me, they have earned my deepest respect by bringing original UNCUT classics such as this, Louis Hayward's Man In The Iron Mask, and Fairbanks Jr.`s The Corsican Brothers (coming in April) to DVD.Hen's Tooth did a pretty good job cleaning this up from the original fine grain print for what they had to work with.  I'm sure if a major company got their hands on it, it would have silkened a bit more.  However, I can't complain.  This is as crisp and clean as I've ever seen it.Donat's Edmund Dantes is like Connery's James Bond.  Yes, there have been other fine actors who carried the role but nothing quite like this.  He has always been a fair-skinned actor.  Given that plus the fine grain film and soft focus lens in the production, it's like watching a ghost.  The additional cast of villains is just solid.  Calhern's DeVillefort is just chilling, and Walbern's Danglars is the perfect skunk.  Sidney Blackmer playing the role of the Spaniard Mondego definitely seemed miscast at first, but it worked well overall with the atmosphere.Also, if you're a nitpicky fan of the book, and have never seen this, the story adjustments may well knock your head back.  I won't reveal too much, although I will say that the fates of the three villains (not four; Caderousse is completely absent) are completely flipped around from both the book and the Chamberlain version from 1975.  It was certainly "Hollywoodized", and the film moves along at a surprisingly fast clip.  Given the time it was made (1934), that was a common tactic in filmmaking.  Overall, getting this DVD in the mail, I feel like Edmund finally getting the Spada fortune!

reviewText: This is an old film and I am sure the original prints were not well maintained. So, Hen's Tooth probably did about as well as could be expected with this print.  That said, I gave it 4 stars; if there were a better copy available, I would give it 3 stars.  As another reviewer stated, it might have been better had it been restored by Criterion.  This print is certainly watchable and entertaining but do expect an occasional flaw to pass through the video. I thought it was worth the purchase price.  I have read the Dumas book several times and no film version comes really close to the book; they hit the basic high points of the story line but miss most of the finer details.
